existing_features.title: Create the main game screen for a mobile-friendly web app titled "Word Hunt Game" that plays as a word-hunt/word-search puzzle.

Implement a word-hunt puzzle mechanic: generate a letter grid that hides words from the provided list and allows the player to find them by dragging/touch-selecting contiguous letters in a straight line (horizontal, vertical, or diagonal; forward or backward).

Include and use exactly the following hunt word list (uppercase) as the source of words to place and find: FLUIDS, CHEMICALS, BATTERY, WIPER, SHOCKABSORBER, ALTERNATOR, WHEELBEARING, DRIVEBELT, TIMINGBELT, CVJOINTBOOT, BRAKELIGHTBULB, HEADLIGHTBULB, INTERIORBULB, LICENSEPLATEBULB, PARKLIGHTBULB, THIRDBRAKELIGHTBULB, IGNITIONCOIL, COMPRESSOR, CVJOINT, DRIVESHAFT, RACKEND, TIERODEND, EVAPORATOR, AIRFILTER, CABINAIRFILTER, FUELFILTER, OILFILTER, POLLENFILTER, TRANSMISSIONFILTER, CAMSHAFTCOVERGASKET, BALLJOINT, TAILLIGHTLAMP, STABILIZERLINK, PAGOIL, BRAKEPADS, SPARKPLUG, DRIVEBELTIDLERPULLEY, WATERPUMP, RADIATOR, BRAKEROTOR, OILPANDRAINPLUGSEAL, BRAKESHOE, STARTER, DRIVEBELTTENSIONER, TIMINGBELTSET.
Provide basic game controls: "New Game" to regenerate a fresh puzzle and a visible counter/progress indicator showing how many words are found out of total.
Choose and apply a coherent visual theme for a word-hunt game (colors, typography, spacing, and component styling) and enforce it consistently across all screens.

Add the user-uploaded image as the app logo by rendering it in the top header of the Word Hunt Game screen (alongside the "Word Hunt Game" title) in a way that remains mobile-friendly and does not disrupt the existing header layout.
Store the selected logo image in the frontend public static assets and reference it consistently from the header (use a stable path under frontend/public/assets/).

Update the Word Hunt Game UI to use a blue color theme consistently across the app, replacing the current amber/orange accents in global theme tokens and in component-level gradient/accent classes (header, buttons, progress bar, selected-cell highlight, badges, and links).
Add an in-game timer that tracks and displays the elapsed time for the current puzzle/game session, resetting when the player starts a new game.
Add a difficulty selector with three levels (Easy, Normal, Hard) and use the selected difficulty to generate puzzles with different gameplay parameters (at minimum, grid size).
Remove the difficulty selector feature (Easy / Normal / Hard) from the Word Hunt Game UI and gameplay so the puzzle always uses a single default grid size.
Change the in-game timer from counting up (elapsed time) to counting down (remaining time) for each puzzle session, resetting to a fixed start duration whenever the player starts a new game.
Add a mobile-friendly UI control that lets the player set the countdown timer duration (the starting time for each puzzle) before starting a new game.

Update the Word Hunt game state/timer logic so the countdown start duration is configurable based on the player’s selected value, and the timer resets to that selected duration whenever a new puzzle starts.
Add PWA support to the existing Word Hunt Game web app so it can be installed and used as the basis for an Android APK build (web app manifest, app icons, and required HTML metadata).

Provide repository documentation that explains how to produce an installable Android APK from the existing app build output (including prerequisites and step-by-step commands), without requiring any changes to the Motoko backend.

Update and complete the existing Android APK packaging documentation so a developer can reliably produce an installable Android APK for the current Word Hunt Game PWA build output, using either Bubblewrap TWA or Capacitor, without requiring any Motoko/backend changes.
Add a committed Android packaging project (using Capacitor) in the repo so a developer can build an installable Android APK for the current Word Hunt Game PWA without changing the Motoko backend.

Update the existing Android APK documentation to include the exact repo-specific commands for building the APK from this repository after the Capacitor Android project is added (including where to find the generated APK outputs).
Add a repository script/command that performs an end-to-end Android APK build using the existing Capacitor Android project, producing an installable APK artifact without any Motoko/backend changes.
Update `frontend/ANDROID_APK.md` to include the exact one-command build invocation added in REQ-20 and explicitly state the expected APK output path(s).

Update the existing one-command Android APK build script (`frontend/scripts/build-android-apk.sh`) to produce a clearly named, stable output artifact by copying the generated debug APK into a deterministic folder in the repo (e.g., `frontend/android-apk-output/`) after a successful build.
Investigate the current build/deployment failure and make the minimal code/configuration changes needed so a clean build and deployment completes successfully.

Update the one-command Android APK build script to validate that the installed Java version meets the Android project requirement (Java 17), and fail fast with a clear English error message when it does not.
Update the Android APK documentation to reflect the Java 17 requirement consistently with the Android project Gradle configuration.

Update the one-command Android APK build script (`frontend/scripts/build-android-apk.sh`) to produce a deterministic, clearly named APK artifact by copying the generated debug APK into a stable repo folder (e.g., `frontend/android-apk-output/`) after a successful build.

Update the one-command Android APK build script (`frontend/scripts/build-android-apk.sh`) to support building a release APK (in addition to debug) and to copy the resulting APK into `frontend/android-apk-output/` with a deterministic, clearly named filename.

Update `frontend/ANDROID_APK.md` to document how to produce the final (release) APK using the repository’s one-command build script, including the exact command(s) and the deterministic output path(s) under `frontend/android-apk-output/`.

Update the existing one-command Android APK build script (`frontend/scripts/build-android-apk.sh`) to support generating a production-ready **signed** release APK in addition to the current unsigned release APK, without committing any keystore files to the repository.

Add Gradle release signing configuration for the Android app that can be enabled via environment variables (or a local, git-ignored properties file) so that release builds can produce a signed APK suitable for direct installation/download distribution.

Update `frontend/ANDROID_APK.md` to document how to produce the final downloadable release APK using the repo’s one-command script, including both unsigned and signed release outputs and their exact deterministic output paths under `frontend/android-apk-output/`.

Update the one-command Android APK build script (`frontend/scripts/build-android-apk.sh`) so that after a successful APK build it also publishes a copy of the APK into the web build output folder (`frontend/dist/`) under a stable URL path (e.g., `frontend/dist/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk`) while keeping the existing deterministic artifact outputs in `frontend/android-apk-output/` unchanged.

Add a visible, mobile-friendly UI control on the main Word Hunt screen that allows the user to download the latest Android APK from the deployed web app via a direct link to `/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk`. User-facing text must be in English.

Update `frontend/ANDROID_APK.md` to document how to build and obtain the APK for immediate download, including: (1) the one-command build invocation(s), (2) the deterministic artifact paths under `frontend/android-apk-output/` for debug/unsigned release/signed release, and (3) the published web-download path under `frontend/dist/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk` and its corresponding URL `/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk`.

Run a fresh end-to-end Android APK build using the existing one-command script (`frontend/scripts/build-android-apk.sh`) and publish the newly built APK into the web build output at `frontend/dist/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk` so the deployed app’s download link `/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk` serves the latest build.

Run a fresh end-to-end Android APK build using the existing one-command script (`frontend/scripts/build-android-apk.sh`) and ensure the APK is published into the web build output at `frontend/dist/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk` so that the deployed site serves the latest APK at the URL path `/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk`.
Verify that the in-app Android download control becomes visible by confirming the runtime APK availability check succeeds (the UI should display the download button labeled in English).

Generate a fresh Android APK for the current deployed draft using the repository’s existing one-command build script, and ensure the resulting APK is published so the deployed web app serves it at `/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk`.

Update the one-command Android APK build script (`frontend/scripts/build-android-apk.sh`) to publish the newly built APK to the deployed web asset path so that the deployed site serves the file at `/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk` (i.e., ensure the build output contains `frontend/dist/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk` and that the repo static directory `frontend/public/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk` is also kept in sync if it is used by the deployment pipeline).

Add a fail-fast verification step at the end of `frontend/scripts/build-android-apk.sh` that checks the published APK exists and is non-empty at `frontend/dist/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk` (and, if applicable, `frontend/public/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk`), and prints clear English instructions if the file is missing so APK packaging retries do not silently succeed while the download remains unavailable.

Ensure the in-app APK availability check results in the Word Hunt screen showing the download control once `/downloads/word-hunt-latest.apk` is present, so that a successful packaging retry makes the "Download APK" button visible without any manual client-side steps.
